study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) on platelet function in patients with coronary artery disease (CAD) undergoing cardiac rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study found that symptom-limited cardiopulmonary exercise testing (CPET) increased platelet aggregation in CAD patients, primarily due to platelet count augmentation rather than single platelet activation, despite antiplatelet therapy. All patients completed CPET without adverse cardiac events.
population_specificity: 28 patients (24 men, 4 women; average age 54.6 ± 8 years) with stable CAD, divided into Aspirin-treated (n=11) and dual-antiplatelet-treated (DAPT, n=17) groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) and moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) on endothelial function and hemodynamics in postmenopausal females, with training load equalized.
results_summary: HIIT significantly improved flow-mediated dilatation (FMD) in postmenopausal females (p < 0.01) and was more effective than MICT in enhancing endothelial function. Both HIIT and MICT showed statistically significant improvements in FMD.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal females
effective_dosage: Not specified (training intensity was 40% maximum heart reserve for low-intensity group; HIIT and MICT details not fully described)
study_duration: 8 weeks for HIIT and MICT groups; 12 weeks for low-intensity group

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a combined high-intensity interval training (HIIT) and moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) program versus MICT alone on health-related quality of life in patients with severe obesity.
results_summary: Both HIIT/MICT and MICT programs moderately improved general health, vitality, social functioning, physical function, and self-esteem scores, with no significant differences between the groups. Tiredness, back pain, and physical stamina also showed moderate to strong improvements in both groups.
population_specificity: Patients with severe obesity (55% female, n=71).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 12-week supervised HIIT program could improve prostate cancer-specific anxiety, fear of cancer progression, quality of life, and psychosocial outcomes in men with prostate cancer on active surveillance.
results_summary: HIIT significantly improved prostate cancer-specific anxiety, fear of progression, hormonal symptoms, perceived stress, fatigue, and self-esteem compared to usual care. Adherence to HIIT was high (96%), and the intervention showed clinically meaningful benefits.
population_specificity: Men with prostate cancer undergoing active surveillance (n=52, randomized to HIIT or usual care).
effective_dosage: Thrice weekly supervised aerobic HIIT sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of HIIT programs (short and long) and MICT on functional capacity and quality of life in patients with coronary artery disease (CAD).
results_summary: Both HIIT programs were superior to MICT in improving maximal exercise capacity (VO2max), but only the MICT group showed a statistically significant improvement in quality of life. No significant differences were found between groups for 6MWT distance or quality of life improvements.
population_specificity: 20 patients with CAD (mean age 60.95 ± 5.08 years) who had undergone revascularization surgery.
effective_dosage: Not specified (24-session exercise-based cardiac rehabilitation program).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of aerobic exercise training in cardiac rehabilitation, with a focus on the benefits and utility of high-intensity interval training across different clinical populations.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that high-intensity interval training is beneficial and effective in improving cardiorespiratory fitness in cardiac rehabilitation settings, though it does not provide specific statistical outcomes. The study emphasizes the importance of personalized exercise prescription for optimized results.
population_specificity: Clinical populations commonly seen in cardiac rehabilitation settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of a HIIT program on cardiorespiratory fitness (CRF) in patients with inflammatory joint disease (IJD) and evaluate its impact on CVD risk, disease activity, feasibility in primary care, and validity of non-exercise algorithms for CRF detection.
results_summary: The study is a randomized controlled trial evaluating HIIT's effects on CRF (primary outcome), CVD risk factors, disease activity, and patient-reported outcomes. Results will be assessed at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months, but specific findings are not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with inflammatory joint disease (IJD) recruited from a Preventive Cardio-Rheuma clinic in Norway.
effective_dosage: HIIT sessions prescribed at 90%-95% of peak heart rate (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) alone and in combination with vitamin B12 and magnesium supplementation on migraine attacks and inflammatory status in women.
results_summary: The study found that the combination of HIIT and supplementation (HIIT + Supp) significantly reduced serum CGRP levels and improved migraine disability assessment scores (MIDAS), frequency, intensity, and duration compared to other groups. The synergistic effects of HIIT and supplementation were more effective than either intervention alone.
population_specificity: Women with migraine attacks.
effective_dosage: Not specified for HIIT; supplementation included vitamin B12 and magnesium (amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether different exercise intensities, including High-Intensity Interval Training, differentially affect gut microbiome composition and function in low-active individuals with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding High-Intensity Interval Training's effects on the gut microbiome.
population_specificity: Low-active individuals with type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of HIIT on body composition, cardiovascular markers, and arterial stiffness in female university students with normal weight obesity (NWO).
results_summary: HIIT significantly improved body composition (reduced fat mass, increased muscle mass), lowered heart rate and blood pressure, improved blood lipid metabolism, and reduced arterial stiffness markers (AVI, API).
population_specificity: Female university students with normal weight obesity (NWO).
effective_dosage: 3 bouts of 9-minute intervals at 90% of maximal heart rate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) could improve cardiopulmonary reserve (peak oxygen consumption) in adults aged 45-85 undergoing major abdominal surgery.
results_summary: The study found a significant improvement in peak oxygen consumption in the HIIT group compared to standard care, with 46 out of 63 participants completing both cardiopulmonary exercise tests and 50 completing clinical follow-up.
population_specificity: Adults aged 45-85 undergoing major abdominal surgery.
effective_dosage: 14 sessions of HIIT over 4 weeks, each session involving approximately 30 minutes of stationary cycling with alternating 1-minute high-intensity (goal of reaching 90% max heart rate) and low/moderate-intensity intervals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of HIIT and MICT on body composition, cardiovascular fitness, and metabolic indices in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: The study found that MICT showed statistically significant within-group differences in weight index, but HIIT's specific results were not detailed in the provided abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) recruited from a hospital in Yangpu, Shanghai.
effective_dosage: HIIT involved one-minute power cycling (80%-95% VO2max) followed by one-minute rest (25%-30% VO2max), repeated for eight rounds; MICT involved 30 minutes of continuous cycling (50%-70% VO2max) five times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) in reducing pain perception and negative emotional states in males with chronic joint pain.
results_summary: HIIT significantly reduced sensory and affective pain experiences, present pain intensity, and symptoms of depression, anxiety, and stress in patients with chronic joint pain during post-test and follow-up stages.
population_specificity: 160 male outpatients with chronic joint pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing knowledge on mitochondrial characteristics in women with PCOS and assess the effects of exercise interventions, particularly HIIT, on metabolic and mitochondrial health.
results_summary: The review found that while HIIT and other exercise interventions improve metabolic health in women with PCOS, evidence on mitochondrial function is limited and inconclusive, with most studies focusing on skeletal muscle and few on adipose tissue. Only one study specifically investigated HIIT, highlighting the need for further research.
population_specificity: Pre-menopausal women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) versus non-exercise control and moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) on postprandial glucose and insulin levels in individuals with normal and impaired glucose.
results_summary: HIIT significantly reduced glucose and insulin AUC compared to non-exercise controls, particularly in individuals with impaired glucose and following moderate-duration interventions. However, no significant differences were found between HIIT and MICT in glucose or insulin AUC.
population_specificity: Participants with both normal and impaired glucose levels.
study_duration: Short-duration (< 8 weeks) and moderate-duration (≥ 8 weeks) interventions

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of home-based HIIT and MICT on functional capacity and health outcomes in patients with myocardial infarction.
results_summary: Both HIIT and MICT improved functional capacity, reduced resting blood pressure and heart rate, and enhanced pulmonary function, muscle strength, and quality of life, with HIIT showing greater effectiveness in improving pulmonary functions and lower extremity muscle strength.
population_specificity: Patients with myocardial infarction (n=21).
effective_dosage: HIIT at 85-95% of heart rate reserve and MICT at 70-75% of heart rate reserve, twice a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically examine the acute and chronic effects of different exercise modalities, including High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT), on circulating endothelial progenitor cells (EPCs) in patients with cardiovascular and metabolic diseases.
results_summary: HIIT acutely increased EPC mobilization in chronic heart failure (CHF) and increased EPCs in hypertensive metabolic syndrome and heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. The clinical condition and exercise modality influenced the degree of EPC mobilization.
population_specificity: Patients with cardiovascular and metabolic diseases, including CHF, coronary artery disease (CAD), peripheral arterial disease (PAD), and metabolic syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of high-intensity interval training (HIT) on menstrual frequency, as a proxy for reproductive function, in women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in menstrual frequency between the high-volume HIT, low-volume HIT, and control groups after 12 months, though menstrual frequency increased in all groups. More participants in the low-volume HIT group became pregnant compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Women with PCOS in Norway and Australia.
effective_dosage: High-volume HIT and low-volume HIT (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the dose-response effects of a 1-year hybrid-type, multicomponent interval training program (DoIT) on musculoskeletal fitness parameters in inactive overweight and obese adults.
results_summary: The study evaluated the impact of DoIT on musculoskeletal fitness in overweight/obese adults, but specific results regarding effectiveness are not detailed in the provided abstract.
population_specificity: Middle-aged (44.8 ± 5.2 years), inactive overweight/obese adults (BMI 31.2 ± 5.7 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how high-intensity interval training (HIIT) and moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) affect natural killer (NK) cell phenotypes, mitochondrial bioenergetics, and aerobic capacity.
results_summary: Both HIIT and MICT improved mitochondrial bioenergetics, reduced mitochondrial oxidative stress, and increased cytotoxic granule proteins in NK cells. HIIT was superior to MICT in enhancing aerobic capacity.
population_specificity: 60 healthy sedentary males (age ~22 years, BMI ~24 kg·m-2).
effective_dosage: HIIT: 3-min intervals at 80% and 40% maximal O2, 30 min/day, 5 days/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of a HIIT intervention (MOVI-daFit!) on adiposity, physical fitness, and cardiometabolic risk factors in schoolchildren.
results_summary: The study found modest improvements in some outcomes, such as standing long jump in boys, mean arterial pressure, triglyceride/HDL-c ratio, and C-reactive protein, but no significant differences in most other measures.
population_specificity: 562 schoolchildren (9-11 years) from 10 schools in Cuenca, Spain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of four exercise modalities, including High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT), on patients with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: HIIT showed a moderate effect on improving blood lipid and liver enzyme levels in NAFLD patients, ranking second in efficacy among the four exercise interventions (AT+RT > HIIT > RT > AT > control). However, no significant difference was found in alanine aminotransferase and aspartate aminotransferase levels across the groups.
population_specificity: Patients with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) (n=1627, with HIIT group n=53).
effective_dosage: Not specified for HIIT (general recommendation: 4-5 times per week at 50%-70% of maximum heart rate).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of isometric exercise training (IET) versus high-intensity interval training (HIIT) in managing resting blood pressure.
results_summary: HIIT reduced resting blood pressure but was less effective than IET, though it achieved greater reductions in resting heart rate compared to IET. Both modes were efficacious, with IET showing superior BP management.
population_specificity: 1583 participants (672 IET, 911 HIIT), including 612 controls (268 IET, 344 HIIT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) on inflammatory biomarkers, body composition, and its comparative effectiveness to standard aerobic or resistance training in type 2 diabetes patients.
results_summary: HIIT may influence inflammatory biomarkers, with potential links between inflammatory profile changes and fat loss. A controlled diet could further reduce inflammation, but more research is needed to compare HIIT to medium-intensity aerobic exercise for improving inflammatory profiles.
population_specificity: Subjects with type 2 diabetes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether FOS-enriched inulin supplementation enhances gut microbiome changes and peak oxygen uptake (V̇O2peak) improvements in response to high-intensity interval training (HIIT).
results_summary: FOS-enriched inulin did not enhance HIIT-induced V̇O2peak improvements but led to gut microbiome changes linked to greater ventilatory threshold improvements. Participants with higher V̇O2peak responses showed associations with specific microbiome pathways and Bifidobacterium species.
population_specificity: Sedentary, apparently healthy adults (31 women, 9 men; aged 31.8 ± 9.8 y, BMI 25.9 ± 4.3).
effective_dosage: 12 g·d⁻¹ of FOS-enriched inulin or maltodextrin/placebo.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the acute effects of metformin intake on performance, perceived exertion, blood lactate, blood glucose, and neuromuscular parameters during high-intensity interval swimming.
results_summary: Metformin did not affect neuromuscular responses, perceived exertion, or performance, despite an anticipatory peak in blood lactate. The anticipated glucose behavior was not confirmed.
population_specificity: Seven healthy swimmers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the impact of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) versus moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) on bone density, geometry, and strength in adolescents with obesity during weight loss.
results_summary: HIIT led to greater reductions in BMI and fat mass percentage compared to MICT, while also improving multisite bone density, geometry, and strength, including increased bone mineral density, content, and resistance to fracture. Both training groups showed benefits, but HIIT demonstrated superior outcomes in several bone-related metrics.
population_specificity: Adolescents with obesity

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of physical exercise, including High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT), on ADHD symptoms, executive function, and motor abilities in children.
results_summary: Preliminary evidence suggests that both acute and chronic physical exercise, including HIIT, benefit ADHD symptoms, executive function, and motor abilities. Aerobic exercise may increase neurotransmitters like serotonin and dopamine, while perceptual motor and meditation could enhance neuroplasticity and attention.
population_specificity: Children with ADHD
effective_dosage: Moderate to high intensity interval training (specific dosage not detailed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of exercise training, including High-Intensity Interval Training, on cardiorespiratory fitness variables in patients with HFpEF.
results_summary: The study found that exercise training improved peak oxygen uptake (Δpeak VO₂) in HFpEF patients, suggesting potential benefits for cardiorespiratory fitness. The meta-analysis indicated consistent positive effects across included studies.
population_specificity: Adult patients with HFpEF (heart failure with preserved ejection fraction).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine whether motivational coaching could enhance the effectiveness of exercise interventions, including High-Intensity Interval Training, in women with psychosis.
results_summary: Motivational coaching appeared to augment exercise intervention effects, leading to higher physical activity participation. The study suggests motivational coaching may further improve exercise outcomes in this population.
population_specificity: Women with a diagnosis of psychotic disorder (within 5 years of first onset) in Hong Kong.
effective_dosage: 12 sessions of 30-minute High-Intensity Interval Training (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training on symptom management and quality of life in rectal cancer patients undergoing neoadjuvant chemoradiation.
results_summary: Exercise worsened stool frequency, role functioning, emotional functioning, and cognitive functioning during NACRT, and diarrhea and embarrassment after NACRT, though most negative effects dissipated post-treatment.
population_specificity: Rectal cancer patients (N=36) undergoing neoadjuvant chemoradiation.
effective_dosage: Supervised high-intensity interval training during NACRT, followed by unsupervised continuous exercise after NACRT (specific dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Duration of NACRT and post-NACRT period (exact length not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) combined with intensive lower extremity resistance training (RT) versus standard moderate-intensity continuous training (MCT) on peak aerobic exercise capacity (peak Vo2) in women undergoing cardiac rehabilitation.
results_summary: The HIIT group showed a significantly greater increase in peak Vo2 (+23%) and leg strength compared to the control group (+7%). The improvements in both peak Vo2 and leg strength were statistically significant and clinically meaningful.
population_specificity: Women (mean age 65 years, range 43-98) participating in a cardiac rehabilitation program.
effective_dosage: HIIT (90% to 95% of peak heart rate) with higher-intensity lower extremity RT, 3 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) on male factor infertility and seminal markers of inflammation compared to other exercise interventions.
results_summary: HIIT showed moderate effectiveness for improving pregnancy rate (RR = 4.63) and live birth rate (RR = 4.38) but ranked lower than other interventions like CET and MICT. It was also less effective for improving semen quality, oxidative stress, and inflammation markers compared to other training strategies.
population_specificity: Fertile and infertile men (2641 participants across 7 trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 12-week HIIT intervention could safely improve cardiac mass, cardiorespiratory fitness, and quality of life in COVID-19 survivors.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results but hypothesizes that HIIT will improve cardiac mass, cardiorespiratory fitness, and reduce post-COVID-19 symptoms. The study is pre-results, so outcomes are not yet reported.
population_specificity: 40 COVID-19 survivors discharged from the hospital, block-randomized by sex.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness of HIIT on pulmonary function and exercise capacity in individuals with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
results_summary: HIIT improved pulmonary function (FEV), exercise capacity (peak WR, 6MWD), and quality of life but did not significantly reduce dyspnea in COPD patients. The study noted limitations due to heterogeneity and low GRADE evidence for some outcomes.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of low-volume and high-volume HIIT on chronotropic responses during exercise and recovery in post-myocardial infarction patients taking β-blockers, and contrast these with physical activity recommendations alone.
results_summary: Both low- and high-volume HIIT similarly improved chronotropic responses (e.g., increased HRpeak and HRreserve) in post-MI patients, with supervised HIIT being more effective than physical activity recommendations alone. Low-volume HIIT was highlighted as a time-efficient strategy to enhance sympathovagal balance.
population_specificity: Post-myocardial infarction patients (58 ± 8 years) taking β-blockers.
effective_dosage: Supervised HIIT 2 days/week (specific intensity/volume details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of low-volume HIIT versus MICT on body composition in adults with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: Both HIIT and MICT reduced fat mass without changing body weight, with MICT showing additional benefits in reducing android fat mass, while HIIT increased lean mass, particularly in the trunk.
population_specificity: Adults aged 40-60 with metabolic syndrome.
effective_dosage: HIIT sessions included 6 intervals at 90% VO2peak for 1 min, followed by 2 min at 50% VO2peak, 3 days/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of High-Intensity Functional Training (HIFT) and High-Intensity Interval Running (HIIT-R) on aerobic capacity and body composition in untrained female university students.
results_summary: The study compared HIIT-R and HIFT over 12 weeks but did not provide specific results in the abstract. The abstract mentions the interventions but lacks outcome data.
population_specificity: Twenty healthy, untrained female university students (age 20.5 ± 0.7 years).
effective_dosage: HIIT-R: 30 s maximal shuttle run with 30 s recovery; HIFT: multiple functional exercises with a 2:1 work-active recovery ratio.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) and high-intensity interval training (HIIT) on cognition and serum BDNF levels in middle-aged overweight men.
results_summary: Both MICT and HIIT significantly improved cognitive test scores and BDNF levels, with no significant differences between the two exercise regimens. The study suggests that 8 weeks of either MICT or HIIT can effectively enhance cognitive function and BDNF levels in this population.
population_specificity: Sedentary, overweight, middle-aged men

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether low-volume functional high-intensity interval training (F-HIIT) is equivalent to combined training (CT) for improving blood pressure in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found that low-volume F-HIIT was not equivalent to CT for improving blood pressure in postmenopausal women, with only a significant reduction observed in the CT group.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women
effective_dosage: F-HIIT: 10 sets of 60 seconds high-intensity exercises with 60 seconds recovery, 3 times/week; CT: 30 minutes moderate-intensity walking plus 5 resistance exercises, 3 times/week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the short-term effects of high-intensity interval training (HIT) on cardiac allograft vasculopathy (CAV) progression in de novo heart transplant recipients.
results_summary: The study found that the intima area increased by 25% in the entire study population, but it did not directly compare HIT and MICT outcomes in the abstract. OCT data were available for 56 patients, with 23 in the HIT group and 33 in the MICT group.
population_specificity: De novo heart transplant recipients (subgroup of the 81-patient HITTS study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of 12 weeks of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) versus moderate-intensity interval training (MIIT) on hematological and inflammatory markers in overweight/obese youth females.
results_summary: HIIT significantly improved body composition, systolic blood pressure, maximal aerobic speed, and reduced C-reactive protein (CRP), while MIIT showed modest improvements in body mass and BMI Z-score. No significant changes were observed in erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) or hematological markers in either group.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese youth females (aged 16.4±1.0 years).
effective_dosage: HIIT: 2×6-8 repetitions of 30s at 100-110% maximal aerobic speed (MAS), with 30s active recovery at 50% MAS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) and Moderate-Intensity Continuous Training (MICT) on liver fat reduction in adults with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.
results_summary: Both HIIT and MICT moderately reduced liver fat content compared to control, with no significant difference between the two methods. Neither total exercise volume nor energy expenditure was related to changes in liver fat.
population_specificity: Adults with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (745 participants across 19 studies).
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise protocols varied by study).
study_duration: Minimum 2 weeks (specific duration varied by study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) on cardiorespiratory fitness in lung cancer survivors, particularly around the time of oncological treatment.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found significant improvements in cardiorespiratory fitness (VO₂) favoring HIIT over usual care, with a standard mean difference of 2.62 (p < 0.00001). However, the conclusions were limited by the small number of studies and heterogeneous patient populations.
population_specificity: Lung cancer survivors (mean age 58.5–68 years), including those undergoing surgery, radiotherapy, or targeted therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of HIIT/SIT on asthma symptoms, cardiorespiratory functions, and other variables among asthmatic patients.
results_summary: HIIT/SIT protocols showed beneficial effects on asthma patients, including improved forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1), but the studies varied in protocols and only four reported chronic phase effects. More high-methodology studies are needed for clearer conclusions.
population_specificity: Asthmatic patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantitatively examine the effects of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) interventions on sleep quality in adults.
results_summary: The study found that HIIT significantly improved subjective sleep quality (measured by Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index) and objective sleep efficiency (SE). The effect sizes indicated a large increase in sleep quality.
population_specificity: Adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of high-intensity, low-volume interval training (HIIT) versus moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) on insulin resistance, muscle mass, muscle activation, and serum musclin in adults with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: HIIT was not superior to MICT in reducing insulin resistance, carnosine, or musclin, or in increasing skeletal muscle mass. Both training types improved insulin resistance, muscle mass, and body composition.
population_specificity: Adults of both sexes with metabolic syndrome (mean age 50.8 ± 6.0 years, BMI 30.6 ± 4.0 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: HIIT consisted of six intervals with one-minute, high-intensity phases at 90% of peak oxygen consumption (VO₂), three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a home-based HIIT intervention (E-Fit) on bone mineral density, muscle function, and quality of life in adolescent girls with idiopathic scoliosis.
results_summary: The E-Fit group showed marginally significant improvements in whole-body areal BMD at 6 months and some positive benefits for bone health and muscle function, though the study had a small sample size and high attrition.
population_specificity: 40 female adolescents (aged 11-14) with adolescent idiopathic scoliosis (AIS).
effective_dosage: Modified 7-minute HIIT sessions, 5 days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if self-administered 4×4-min HIIT guided by a smartphone app could produce similar improvements in VO₂max and disease activity as supervised HIIT in patients with inflammatory rheumatic diseases.
results_summary: Both supervised and app-guided HIIT significantly improved VO₂max and reduced disease activity in patients with inflammatory rheumatic diseases, with no significant differences between the two methods.
population_specificity: 40 patients (33 female, 7 male) with rheumatoid arthritis, spondyloarthritis, or systemic lupus erythematosus.
effective_dosage: 4×4-min intervals at 85-95% of maximal heart rate, twice weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 5-year exercise intervention, including High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT), and changes in peak oxygen uptake were associated with cognitive function in older adults.
results_summary: Overall, exercise (including HIIT) was not significantly associated with cognition in older adults, though maintaining or increasing peak oxygen uptake appeared to benefit cognition. Men in the combined exercise group showed modest cognitive benefits, but women did not.
population_specificity: 945 older adults (48% women, mean age 78.2 years) from the Generation 100 Study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exercise training, specifically High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT), could increase 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D levels in sedentary adults.
results_summary: The study found that a 12-week HIIT intervention significantly increased 1,25(OH)2D levels compared to the control group, suggesting exercise can counteract vitamin D deficiency. The combination of HIIT with whole-body electromyostimulation (HIIT + EMS) did not show additional benefits over HIIT alone.
population_specificity: 89 healthy sedentary adults (53% women; mean age 53.5 ± 4.9 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise protocols described as HIIT and HIIT + EMS, but exact intensity/frequency not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of different HIIT protocols compared to moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) and a control group on VO₂ max in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The meta-analysis of 20 studies (738 participants) found that HIIT increased VO₂ max more effectively than MICT, suggesting superior cardiovascular benefits for T2DM patients.
population_specificity: Adults with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects and potential mechanisms of exercise, including High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT), on NLRP3 inflammasome activation, focusing on mitochondrial involvement.
results_summary: Chronic exercise, including HIIT, generally inhibits NLRP3 inflammasome activation, while acute exercise activates it. The mechanisms by which exercise regulates NLRP3 inflammasome remain unclear, but mitochondrial pathways are a key focus.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of exercise effects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) improves sleep-dependent procedural memory consolidation in individuals with schizophrenia.
results_summary: HIIT significantly improved sleep-dependent procedural memory consolidation in individuals with schizophrenia, outperforming both aerobic-endurance exercise and psychoeducation. The effect of HIIT was more distinctive compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Individuals with schizophrenia spectrum disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether short-term (<6 weeks) high-intensity interval training (HIIT) improves aerobic fitness in preoperative abdominal cancer patients compared to moderate-intensity exercise training (MIET).
results_summary: Three out of four studies evaluating HIIT showed statistically significant improvements in oxygen uptake at peak exercise (VO2 peak), suggesting HIIT may be more effective than MIET for short-term prehabilitation. The abstract does not provide detailed efficacy comparisons or adverse event data.
population_specificity: Patients with abdominal cancer undergoing preoperative prehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether at-home HIIT, alone or combined with yoga, could reduce depressive symptoms in adults during the COVID-19 pandemic.
results_summary: HIIT significantly reduced depressive symptoms compared to the waitlist control, with small effect sizes in the general sample and very large effects in participants with high baseline depressive symptoms. No significant differences were found between HIIT, yoga, or their combination.
population_specificity: Low-active, English-speaking, non-retired Canadians aged 18-64.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to preliminarily assess the effects of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) and progressive high circuit-resistance training (CRT) on endothelial function, cardiorespiratory fitness, muscle strength, and physical performance in heart failure patients.
results_summary: HIIT improved cardiorespiratory fitness (VO2 peak and METs) and isokinetic torque peak, while CRT improved physical performance (reduced chair stand test time). No significant effects were observed on endothelial function.
population_specificity: Heart failure patients (aged 56 ± 10 years, mainly NYHA class I and II, hemodynamically stable).
effective_dosage: At least 36 exercise sessions (specific frequency not detailed).
study_duration: Duration not explicitly stated, but implied by the number of sessions.

study_goal: To examine the effects of high-intensity interval exercise (HiInEx) on bone health and physical fitness function in schoolchildren compared to other exercise types.
results_summary: High-intensity interval exercise (HiInEx) largely benefited physical fitness function, while high-impact exercise (HiEx) mostly improved bone health, and high-impact exercise with various directions (HiExVi) enhanced both bone health and physical fitness. All groups showed an increment in speed of sound (SOS) compared to baseline.
population_specificity: 174 Chinese boys and girls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Wilder's principle (greater treatment effect with higher baseline levels) applies to the blood pressure-lowering effects of High-Intensity Interval Training in individuals with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results on the effectiveness of High-Intensity Interval Training for blood pressure reduction, only stating that the study was conducted on middle-aged individuals with metabolic syndrome.
population_specificity: Middle-aged individuals (55±8 years) with metabolic syndrome (n=178).
effective_dosage: 3 days per week (specific intensity/duration not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the safety and feasibility of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) in patients with non-muscle invasive bladder cancer (NMIBC) undergoing intravesical therapy, and its potential effects on health-related fitness, patient-reported outcomes, and cancer recurrence/progression.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results as the study is ongoing (pre-results). The trial will evaluate feasibility, preliminary efficacy, and long-term cancer outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with non-muscle invasive bladder cancer (NMIBC) scheduled to receive intravesical therapy.
effective_dosage: Three supervised HIIT sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cognitive effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) on individuals with methamphetamine (MA) dependence.
results_summary: The study suggests that HIIT may reduce illicit drug cravings and improve cognitive functions, such as memory and executive function, in individuals with MA dependence, though final results are pending completion of the trial.
population_specificity: Individuals with methamphetamine (MA) dependence (n=240).
effective_dosage: 24-minute HIIT sessions on a treadmill, 3 times weekly for the first 6 months.
study_duration: 12 months (6 months of intervention, 6 months of follow-up).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize prescribed exercise interventions for children with congenital heart disease (CHD) and identify limitations to exercise training prescription.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that exercise and physical activity are safe and feasible for children with CHD, with potential benefits from home-based interventions and high-intensity interval training, though these remain underutilized in pediatric care.
population_specificity: Children with congenital heart disease (CHD)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential role of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) as a hypothetical intervention for frozen shoulder, alongside other emerging treatments.
results_summary: The abstract mentions HIIT as a still-hypothetical intervention for frozen shoulder, with no concrete evidence or results provided regarding its effectiveness.
population_specificity: Patients with frozen shoulder, particularly those with Diabetes Mellitus or thyroid disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of HIIT, alone or combined with chlorella vulgaris, on mitochondrial biogenesis, performance, and body composition in overweight/obese women.
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in fat mass in the group combining HIIT and chlorella vulgaris compared to the placebo group.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different exercise therapy intensities (light-to-moderate vs. vigorous) affect walking performance and cardiorespiratory fitness in patients with symptomatic lower-extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study analyzed randomized controlled trials and found that exercise intensity influenced improvements in walking performance (pain-free and maximal walking distance) and cardiorespiratory fitness (V̇O₂). However, specific comparative results between intensities were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with symptomatic lower-extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of HIIT on cardiorespiratory fitness and biochemical progression in men with prostate cancer undergoing active surveillance.
results_summary: HIIT increased cardiorespiratory fitness (peak V̇o2) and decreased PSA levels, PSA velocity, and prostate cancer cell growth compared to usual care. No significant differences were found in PSA doubling time or testosterone.
population_specificity: Adult men diagnosed with localized very low risk to favorable intermediate risk prostate cancer undergoing active surveillance.
effective_dosage: Thrice-weekly supervised aerobic sessions on a treadmill at 85% to 95% of peak oxygen consumption (V̇o2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the long-term effects of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) versus moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) on brain structure in older adults over a 5-year period.
results_summary: HIIT was associated with increased hippocampal atrophy (though within normal range) compared to controls, while MICT showed greater thalamic atrophy. Baseline cardiorespiratory fitness (CRF) was positively linked to cortical volume over time, but CRF changes during the intervention did not affect brain structure.
population_specificity: Older adults (70-77 years, 52 women) from the general population.
effective_dosage: HIIT: 4×4 intervals at ~90% peak heart rate, twice weekly; MICT: 50 minutes at ~70% peak heart rate, twice weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether home-based smartphone-supported HIIT (habit-B programme) improves cardiorespiratory fitness in early-stage breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: The HIIT intervention significantly improved peak oxygen uptake and leg strength compared to the control group, but no significant differences were found in other outcomes like fatigue or quality of life.
population_specificity: Women aged 20-59 with stage I-IIa breast cancer who had completed initial treatment (except hormone therapy).
effective_dosage: Not specified (body weight exercises, home-based, smartphone-supported HIIT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of low-volume walking HIIT versus MICT on cardiovascular disease risk and physical capacity in older women with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: HIIT improved resting systolic and diastolic blood pressure and physical capacity (VO2 peak) but did not affect ambulatory blood pressure or lipid profile. Both HIIT and MICT showed similar efficacy in improving some CVD risk factors.
population_specificity: Inactive older women with type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term effects of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) and moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) on cardiovascular risk profiles and fitness in older adults.
results_summary: Five years of supervised HIIT showed a modest improvement in peak oxygen uptake (VO2peak) but no significant reduction in cardiovascular risk score compared to control. HIIT performed slightly better than MICT in some individual risk factors, but overall, exercise training had little effect on cardiovascular risk or events.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 70-77 years from Trondheim, Norway (n = 1567, 50% women), able to safely perform exercise.
effective_dosage: Two weekly sessions of HIIT (∼90% of peak heart rate) or MICT (∼70% of peak heart rate).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantitatively evaluate the effect and safety of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) on obese adolescents to provide a basis for obesity management.
results_summary: HIIT effectively reduced body weight, BMI, body fat percentage, and waist circumference in obese adolescents, with specific HIIT programs showing varying benefits for different metrics.
population_specificity: Obese adolescents (488 participants across 11 RCTs).
effective_dosage: Not specified (HIIT programs categorized as "high-intensity short-interval" and "high-intensity long-interval").

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of 12 weeks of HIIT on circulating adipokines and cardiovascular disease risk factors in obese men.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study investigated HIIT's impact on adipokines and cardiovascular risk factors in obese men.
population_specificity: Thirty men with obesity (age: 24.96±3.11 years, BMI: 30.92±1.04 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of 4 weeks of high-intensity interval exercise (HIIE) training and subsequent detraining on baroreflex sensitivity (BRS) and its vascular and autonomic components in healthy adolescents at rest.
results_summary: The study found that 4 weeks of HIIE training did not significantly alter resting BRS, arterial compliance, or autonomic determinants compared to the control group, with no meaningful effect sizes observed.
population_specificity: Healthy adolescents

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of a home-based, YouTube-delivered physical activity intervention on young adults' free-living physical activity, sedentary behavior, and sleep quality during the COVID-19 pandemic.
results_summary: The intervention led to statistically significant improvements in moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA), sleep efficiency, muscle-strengthening PA frequency, intrinsic motivation, and reduced perceived PA barriers. The effects were clinically meaningful, particularly in enhancing intrinsic motivation and reducing barriers to PA.
population_specificity: Young adults (mean age 22.8 ± 3.4 years, 48 females, BMI 23.1 ± 2.6 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility of using HIIT to induce neurophysiological stress responses potentially linked to mood changes.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding HIIT's effects on mood or neurophysiological stress responses, only stating it was a pilot study for future research.
population_specificity: Twenty-five active male college students (average age 21.7 ± 2.1 years, weight 72.6 ± 8.4 kg, height 177 ± 6.1 cm, BMI 23.1 ± 1.4 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the physiological adaptations and benefits of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) on exercise capacity and metabolic health across various populations.
results_summary: The study found that HIIT induces significant physiological adaptations, improving exercise capacity (e.g., maximal oxygen uptake, aerobic endurance) and metabolic health in both clinical and healthy populations, with benefits comparable to or greater than moderate-intensity continuous training despite lower total exercise volume.
population_specificity: Clinical and healthy populations (athletes, active and inactive individuals without apparent disease or disorder).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a 6-month HIIT intervention in improving aerobic fitness and maintaining BMI in adolescents, with and without asthma.
results_summary: HIIT significantly improved maximal aerobic fitness and maintained BMI in adolescents, regardless of asthma status, but did not affect sub-maximal aerobic fitness, lung function, or quality of life. The intervention was well-tolerated by those with asthma, who showed similar fitness responses as their healthy peers.
population_specificity: 616 adolescents (334 boys; 13.0 ± 1.1 years), including 155 with asthma (78 boys).
effective_dosage: 30 min, 3 times per week, with 10-30 s bouts at >90% age-predicted maximum heart rate and equal rest.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) on exercise capacity and safety in post-myocardial infarction (MI) patients compared to moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) or routine physical activity.
results_summary: HIIT significantly improved peak oxygen uptake (peak VO2) compared to control groups, with no significant differences in blood pressure, heart rate, left ventricular function, or quality of life. The incidence of adverse events was similar between HIIT and control groups, indicating HIIT is safe for post-MI patients.
population_specificity: Post-myocardial infarction (MI) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility of generalist school teachers delivering high-intensity interval training (HIIT) during physical education classes.
results_summary: The HIIT program was feasible and acceptable to teachers and students, with high recruitment (88%) and session delivery (84%). However, the adjusted between-group difference for cardiorespiratory fitness was trivial (effect size 0.02).
population_specificity: 84 students (aged 11.9 ± 0.5 years, 64 male and 19 female) from two schools.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of locomotor high-intensity interval training (HIIT) versus moderate-intensity aerobic training on walking capacity in chronic stroke survivors.
results_summary: The study hypothesized that HIIT would result in greater improvements in walking capacity than moderate-intensity aerobic training, but the abstract does not provide specific results, only the methodology and intended outcomes.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke survivors (6 months to 5 years post-stroke), aged 40-80, with limited walking speed (≤1.0 m/s) and stable cardiovascular condition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of the apelin/APJ system in the locomotor system and how different training modes, including High-Intensity Interval Training, regulate apelin expression.
results_summary: The study found that exercise-induced apelin, including from High-Intensity Interval Training, may serve as a pharmacological agent for treating diseases and regulating physiological processes in the locomotor system. Apelin/APJ system influences bone formation, muscle metabolism, and skeletal muscle production, with varying effects on osteoarthritis and osteoporosis.
population_specificity: Not specified (general locomotor system focus)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of prehabilitation exercise programs, including High-Intensity Interval Training, on perioperative and postoperative outcomes in individuals undergoing elective abdominal aortic aneurysm repair.
results_summary: The study found very low-certainty evidence regarding the impact of prehabilitation exercise on 30-day mortality, pulmonary complications, need for re-intervention, or postoperative bleeding. However, it suggested a possible reduction in cardiac and renal complications compared to usual care (no exercise).
population_specificity: Individuals with clinically diagnosed abdominal aortic aneurysms deemed suitable for elective repair.
effective_dosage: Varied across trials: 3-6 sessions per week, 1 hour per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of a 14-day HIIT intervention combined with oral Longvida supplementation on athletic performance and mental well-being.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that curcumin (via Longvida) may improve athletic performance by reducing post-exercise inflammation and enhancing mental well-being, but specific results are not detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how perceptual-cognitive performance was affected during high-intensity interval training (HIIT) using a 3D-multiple object tracking task.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of HIIT on perceptual-cognitive performance.
population_specificity: 42 healthy adults (age not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of a combined HIIT and resistance training program on anthropometric parameters, physical activity, functional capacity, physiological parameters, and quality of life in older adults with coronary artery disease.
results_summary: The HIIT + R group showed significant improvements in BMI, body fat percentage, waist circumference, physical activity, functional capacity, quality of life, and systolic blood pressure compared to the usual care group. The study concluded that combined HIIT + R training can produce desired health outcomes in this population.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 69.23 ± 4.9 years) with coronary artery disease.
effective_dosage: 8 sessions (1 session per week), each consisting of ten 3-minute bouts (1 minute high-intensity treadmill walking at 85-90% MHR, followed by low-intensity walking at 60-70% MHR, and low-to-moderate resistance training).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) on physical, mental, and cognitive functioning in stroke survivors.
results_summary: HIIT combined with standard care improved walking distance, balance, and executive function immediately post-intervention compared to standard care alone, though only executive function (TMT-B) remained significantly improved at the 12-month follow-up. The control group showed greater improvement in total Functional Independence Measure score at follow-up.
population_specificity: Adult stroke survivors (3 months to 5 years post-first stroke) with a mean age of ~57-59 years.
effective_dosage: 4×4 minutes of treadmill HIIT at 85%-95% of peak heart rate.
study_duration: Duration of intervention not explicitly stated in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether HIIT mitigates physical function impairments, fatigue, and mitochondrial bioenergetics issues in older PLWH more effectively than CME, and whether biobehavioral coaching promotes long-term physical activity adherence.
results_summary: The abstract does not report specific results, but the study design suggests a comparison of HIIT and CME effects on physical function, fatigue, and mitochondrial bioenergetics, with a focus on long-term adherence via coaching.
population_specificity: Older people living with HIV (≥50 years), self-reporting fatigue and leading a sedentary lifestyle.
study_duration: 16 weeks of supervised training, followed by a 12-week maintenance phase.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the acute effect of a single HIIT session on testosterone and cortisol levels in healthy individuals.
results_summary: The study found that testosterone and cortisol levels increased immediately after a single HIIT session, dropped below baseline levels after 120-180 minutes, and returned to baseline after 24 hours. HIIT components and participant characteristics moderated these effects.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training on weight loss and related outcomes in individuals with obesity.
results_summary: The study found that High-Intensity Interval Training had a modest effect on weight loss, amounting to only a few kg, but it may contribute to improvements in V̇O₂.
population_specificity: Persons with obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of a 12-week HIIT plus lifestyle education program on quality of life, behavioral, and psychosocial outcomes among inactive adults with coeliac disease.
results_summary: Participants in the HIIT group reported significant improvements in quality of life, exercise behavior, gastrointestinal symptoms, and self-compassion immediately post-intervention, which were sustained three months later, while the waitlist control group showed no changes. All participants improved adherence to a gluten-free diet post-intervention.
population_specificity: Inactive adults with coeliac disease
effective_dosage: Twice-weekly HIIT sessions progressing to 14 × 30-second intervals at 90% HRmax, with 2-minute recovery at 50% HRmax

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of an 8-week HIIT intervention on patient-reported outcomes and physical function in breast cancer patients undergoing anthracycline-based chemotherapy.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in physical function (Margaria-Kalamen stair climb test and 6MWT) in the HIIT group compared to baseline and the control group, but no changes in patient-reported outcomes, TUG, or 30STS were observed in either group.
population_specificity: Breast cancer patients undergoing anthracycline-based chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: HIIT sessions three days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) on heart rate variability (HRV) in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: HIIT improved the LF/HF ratio, a key HRV parameter, in T2DM patients, though its effects on other HRV parameters were less consistent compared to endurance training. Supervised training appeared beneficial, but HIIT's overall impact was narrower than endurance exercise.
population_specificity: 523 T2DM patients (472 in exercise groups, 151 controls).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effects of aerobic exercise, including High-Intensity Interval Training, on serum biomarkers related to neuroplasticity and brain repair in stroke survivors.
results_summary: A single bout of High-Intensity Interval Training significantly increased BDNF, IGF-1, and VEGF levels, while an 8-week continuous aerobic exercise program also increased BDNF levels. No significant effects were found for other serum biomarkers.
population_specificity: Adult survivors of stroke
effective_dosage: Single bout of High-Intensity Interval Training; 40-45-minute sessions, 24 sessions over 8 weeks for continuous aerobic exercise

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of exercise intervention programs, including High-Intensity Interval Training, on cardiometabolic health indicators (blood pressure, insulin resistance, and intrahepatic fat) in adults with overweight or obesity.
results_summary: Exercise training significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure and showed positive effects on insulin resistance and intrahepatic fat, with statistically significant results (p < 0.00001). The meta-analysis included 54 randomized controlled trials, indicating consistent benefits across studies.
population_specificity: Adults with overweight or obesity

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of eight weeks of HIIT versus stretching on impulsivity levels and inflammatory-mediated changes in the kynurenine pathway in emotionally impulsive humans.
results_summary: HIIT increased aerobic fitness, reduced interleukin 6 levels, and shifted the kynurenine pathway from neurotoxic to neuroprotective activity, correlating with decreased impulsivity. Both interventions reduced emotion-related impulsivity, but only HIIT reduced emotion-unrelated impulsivity.
population_specificity: Emotionally impulsive humans

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) on plasma steroid hormone levels in physically inactive, middle-aged adults.
results_summary: HIIT, with or without whole-body electromyostimulation (EMS), significantly increased dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate, testosterone, and free testosterone while reducing cortisol levels. The PAR program showed slight improvements compared to HIIT and HIIT+EMS despite higher training volume.
population_specificity: Physically inactive, middle-aged adults (45-65 years old, 36 women, 67 total participants).
effective_dosage: HIIT: 40-65 min/week at >95% of maximum oxygen uptake (long intervals) and >120% of maximum oxygen uptake (short intervals).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the efficiency and safety of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) in patients recently discharged with intermediate-high-risk acute pulmonary embolism (PE).
results_summary: HIIT significantly improved exercise capacity (eV˙O2max), lung function (FEV1), right ventricular function (RV/LV ratio), and health-related quality of life (HRQoL) without serious adverse events. The control group showed no improvement in most outcomes, with a slight decline in FEV1.
population_specificity: 24 patients (5 women) recently discharged with intermediate-high-risk acute PE.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether short-term High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) could improve physical fitness and maintain adaptations after a period of detraining in sedentary, middle-age men.
results_summary: HIIT increased lean mass (+1.6%), muscle strength (+10%), and aerobic capacity (+14%), with gains in lean mass and strength maintained after detraining, though aerobic capacity declined. HIIT showed comparable benefits to resistance training in maintaining muscle adaptations post-detraining.
population_specificity: Sedentary, middle-age men (average age 39 ± 3 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified (6 weeks of HIIT, frequency not detailed).
study_duration: 6 weeks of training followed by 2.5 weeks of detraining.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the role of HIIT in promoting neuroplasticity and cognitive functions after stroke, as well as its potential preventive role in stroke severity.
results_summary: HIIT shows promise in enhancing neurotrophic factors, neurogenesis, and synaptic plasticity in both stroke and healthy individuals, with potential cognitive benefits when combined with cognitive tasks. However, methodological limitations and the need for further research on neuroplasticity's clinical role were noted.
population_specificity: Stroke patients and healthy individuals (humans and rodents).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of technique-specific HIIT versus traditional taekwondo training on physical fitness and body composition in taekwondo athletes, as well as analyze inter-individual responses.
results_summary: The study compared HIIT and traditional training but did not provide explicit results in the abstract. It measured outcomes like squat jump, countermovement jump, sprint performance, agility, and kicking speed.
population_specificity: Sixteen male and female taekwondo athletes (5 females, 11 males).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of different exercise patterns, including High-Intensity Interval Training, on eight indicators in patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: The study found that aerobic exercises, including High-Intensity Interval Training, significantly improved eight indicators in NAFLD patients, such as triglycerides (TG), with statistically significant results.
population_specificity: Patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and quantify the effect of acute High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) on executive function (EF) and identify factors influencing this relationship.
results_summary: Acute HIIT had a positive effect on overall EF in 61% of outcomes across 24 studies. Factors such as EF components (inhibition, updating), assessment timing (within 30 min), exercise duration (11-30 min), and age (under 40 years) moderated the effect.
population_specificity: Not specified beyond age under 40 years as a potential moderating factor.
effective_dosage: Not specified (focus on acute HIIT sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of 6 months of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) on cardiometabolic risk in adolescents with and without asthma.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of HIIT on arterial stiffness or clustered cardiometabolic risk in adolescents, though it was associated with lower low-density lipoprotein and diastolic blood pressure at mid-intervention. No interaction effects between asthma and HIIT were observed.
population_specificity: 65 adolescents (31 with mild asthma, 34 without asthma)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a HIIT-style vigorous physical activity intervention delivered during school PE could improve cardiorespiratory fitness, cognitive performance, and mental health in young adolescents.
results_summary: The intervention did not significantly improve cardiorespiratory fitness, cognitive performance (executive functions, relational memory, or processing speed), or mental health. High drop-out and low compliance were noted.
population_specificity: Year 8 pupils (n=18,261, aged 12-13) from 104 secondary state schools in South/Mid-England.
effective_dosage: Additional 10 minutes of vigorous physical activity per PE lesson.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) on liver fat content in overweight or obese adults with metabolic disorders.
results_summary: HIIT was found to significantly reduce liver fat compared to a control group, but no significant difference was observed when compared to moderate-intensity interval training (MICT). The results suggest HIIT can improve liver fat in this population independent of weight loss.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese adults with metabolic disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the acute and training effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) versus standard moderate continuous training (MCT) on plasma neurofilament light chain (pNfL) and kynurenine (KYN) pathway metabolites in persons with multiple sclerosis (pwMS).
results_summary: Acute HIIT reduced pNfL and increased neuroprotective kynurenic acid (KA), with HIIT showing consistently greater effects than MCT. After 3 weeks, HIIT activated the KYN pathway more than MCT, suggesting potential neuroprotective benefits.
population_specificity: Persons with multiple sclerosis (Expanded Disability Status Scale score 3.0-6.0).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of a 12-week endurance exercise training intervention (including HIIT) on hs-cTnT levels in stable HFrEF patients and associations between hs-cTnT and peak oxygen uptake.
results_summary: The study found that a 12-week exercise intervention was associated with reduced hs-cTnT levels across all groups (HIIT, MCT, RRE) when adjusted for clinical variables. Higher peak oxygen uptake was linked to lower hs-cTnT concentrations.
population_specificity: Stable patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF; left ventricular ejection fraction ≤ 35%), mean age 61.2 years, 19% women.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention details like intensity/frequency not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of exercise training, including High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT), on serum chemerin concentrations in individuals with overweight and/or obesity.
results_summary: The study found that while aerobic, resistance, and combined training decreased serum chemerin concentrations, HIIT did not show a significant effect. The reduction in chemerin was linked to declines in body fat percentage.
population_specificity: Individuals with overweight and/or obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current literature on adherence to High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) in cardiac rehabilitation patients with coronary artery disease.
results_summary: Adherence to HIIT session attendance was high and comparable to moderate-intensity exercise, but adherence to intensity and duration was variable and underreported. The review highlights the need for better measurement and reporting of adherence and further research on home-based and long-term HIIT adherence.
population_specificity: Cardiac rehabilitation patients with coronary artery disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal BMI and FMI values for the lowest risk of failure in aerobic performance improvement after HIIT using the Tabata protocol in adolescents.
results_summary: The study found that FMI had a stronger effect on physical efficiency index (PEI) than BMI, with the lowest risk of no positive effects in PEI observed in the BMI range of 19.01-22.00 kg/m². The model for FMI showed higher accuracy in predicting outcomes.
population_specificity: 73 adolescent students

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of sprint interval training (SIT), high-intensity interval training (HIIT), and moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) on cardiorespiratory fitness (peak oxygen uptake, VO₂).
results_summary: The study examined the impact of 12 weeks of HIIT, SIT, and MICT on VO₂, but the abstract does not specify the comparative results or outcomes for HIIT.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the settings and outcomes of HIIT interventions for breast cancer survivors and explore the feasibility of prescribing such exercise.
results_summary: The review found that HIIT improved cardiorespiratory fitness in breast cancer survivors, with interventions typically supervised and lab-based. Further research is needed to assess effects on other outcomes.
population_specificity: Breast cancer survivors (during or after treatment)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-intensity interval training (HIIT), continuous aerobic exercise training (CAET), and no-exercise control on reproductive, anthropometric, and cardiometabolic outcomes in women with PCOS.
results_summary: Both HIIT and CAET improved anthropometrics and some cardiometabolic health markers, but adherence challenges limited the analysis of their effects on ovulation. CAET showed a significant reduction in body mass index compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Previously inactive women aged 18-40 years with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effectiveness of exercise therapy, particularly High-Intensity Interval Training, on functional capacity, cardiovascular health, and health-related quality of life in adult heart transplant patients.
results_summary: High-Intensity Interval Training led to larger improvements in exercise capacity, especially in patients with cardiac reinnervation, and clinically relevant reductions in ambulatory blood pressure. Limited data also suggested improved quality of life post-training.
population_specificity: Adult heart transplant patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of a 6-week home-based upper-body HIIT intervention on biomarkers of cardiometabolic health in individuals with spinal cord injury compared to a control group.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results, as it describes a planned randomized controlled trial. Outcomes will assess body composition, glycaemic control, blood lipids, inflammation, aerobic capacity, and other health markers.
population_specificity: Individuals aged 18-65 with chronic paraplegia (spinal cord lesion between T2 and L2).
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of arm crank-based HIIT (60s intervals at 80-90% peak heart rate) four times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a 12-week HIIT program versus MICT and usual care on resting NK-cell function and circulating myokines in women at high risk for breast cancer.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between HIIT, MICT, and usual care in changes to NK-cell function or circulating myokines. However, baseline fitness levels correlated with changes in NK-cell function, suggesting exercise may benefit those with lower cardiorespiratory fitness more.
population_specificity: Women at high risk for breast cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the most effective exercise dosage (modality, intensity, duration, and amount) for reducing visceral adipose tissue (VAT), with a focus on high-intensity interval training (HIIT).
results_summary: HIIT (SMD -0.39, 95% CI -0.60 to -0.18) and aerobic exercise of at least moderate intensity were beneficial for reducing VAT, while resistance exercise and sprint interval training showed no significant effects. Effective dosage for HIIT was less than 30 min or 30-60 min per session, three times per week for 12-16 weeks.
population_specificity: General population (n=1962 across 34 studies)
effective_dosage: 3 times per week, sessions lasting less than 30 min or 30-60 min

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-intensity interval training (HIIT) had different effects on peak oxygen consumption (peak V̇o2) compared to moderate continuous training and guideline-based physical activity in patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF).
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant difference in peak V̇o2 change at 3 months between HIIT and moderate continuous training, and neither group met the prespecified clinically important difference compared to guideline control. No significant changes in diastolic function or natriuretic peptides were observed, and adverse events like acute coronary syndrome were reported in small numbers across groups.
population_specificity: Sedentary patients with chronic, stable HFpEF (mean age 70 years, 67% women).
effective_dosage: 3 sessions per week, 38 minutes per session.
study_duration: 12 months (3 months in-clinic, 9 months home-based with telemedical supervision).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of HIIT on body composition, cardiopulmonary function, and perceived quality of life in bariatric surgery patients compared to MICT and a control group.
results_summary: The study expects HIIT to improve body composition, cardiopulmonary function, and quality of life after 16 weeks, with HIIT potentially showing greater benefits than MICT. Results are pending as the study is exploratory and outcomes are measured at multiple time points.
population_specificity: 75 adults of both sexes scheduled for bariatric surgery.
effective_dosage: 2 days a week (specific HIIT protocol details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the isolated and combined effects of high-intensity interval training and time-restricted eating on glycaemic control in reproductive-aged women with overweight/obesity.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of high-intensity interval training, as the study appears to be ongoing or not yet concluded.
population_specificity: Reproductive-aged women (18-45 years) with a body mass index ≥27 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of periodized high-intensity exercise training versus conventional endurance training on exercise capacity, body composition, and muscle strength in persons with Multiple Sclerosis.
results_summary: Periodized high-intensity exercise training resulted in larger improvements in exercise capacity despite requiring 57% less peak-effort training time compared to classic endurance training. The study suggests periodized training may be more effective for functional rehabilitation in MS.
population_specificity: Thirty-one persons with Multiple Sclerosis (all phenotypes, mean EDSS 2.3±1.3).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-intensity interval training (HIIT) was superior to low-intensity training or usual care in improving cardiopulmonary function, lipid profiles, and in-stent restenosis in patients after percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).
results_summary: The meta-analysis of six RCTs (247 patients) found that HIIT significantly improved left ventricular ejection function (LVEF) compared to control interventions, with a standardized mean difference of 0.38 (95% CI [0.03, 0.73]).
population_specificity: Patients who underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) to promote muscle growth and cardiorespiratory fitness, particularly in populations susceptible to muscle loss.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that HIIT places high tensile stress on skeletal muscle, resembling resistance exercise, and may induce muscle growth alongside rapid increases in oxidative capacity, though its anabolic potential has received less scientific inquiry. The review discusses molecular responses supporting HIIT's implementation in vulnerable populations or clinical settings.
population_specificity: Middle-aged or older adults and clinical populations (e.g., pre- or post-surgery).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) is as effective as Hydrochlorothiazide (HCTZ) in lowering 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure in prehypertensive older adults and whether HIIT offers greater cardiovascular and cognitive benefits.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a comparison between HIIT and HCTZ but does not report final results. It is designed to assess non-inferiority of HIIT for blood pressure reduction and potential superiority in cardiovascular and cognitive outcomes.
population_specificity: Prehypertensive adults aged 60 years or older.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a 5-year high-intensity interval training intervention on metabolic syndrome (MetS) management, health-related variables, and medication use.
results_summary: The exercise group showed a tendency for reduced MetS factors and increased cardiorespiratory fitness, while medication use increased significantly in the control group but remained stable in the exercise group. The proportion of medicated patients requiring increased medication was lower in the exercise group.
population_specificity: Adults (average age 54 years, 20-38% women) with metabolic syndrome.
effective_dosage: High-intensity interval training on a cycloergometer three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of self-tailored HIIT and MICE on cardiorespiratory fitness in patients early after ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) and assess the feasibility of HIIT in this population.
results_summary: Both HIIT and MICE improved peak VO₂, but HIIT was more strenuous without being superior or more time-efficient than MICE. Self-tailored HIIT was feasible in patients early after STEMI.
population_specificity: 69 males starting cardiac rehabilitation within 4 weeks after STEMI.
