effective_dosage: HIIT: 2×HIIT and 1×MICE per week (4×4-min intervals above the second ventilatory threshold); MICE: 3×MICE per week (workload at first ventilatory threshold).
study_duration: 9 weeks (after a 3-week run-in phase with MICE).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and efficacy potential of a 12-week aerobic and resistance training program, including High-Intensity Interval Training, on cognitive and physical performance outcomes in people with HIV.
results_summary: The 12-week exercise program improved physical performance measures (effect sizes: 0.2 - 1.5) but did not yield reliable cognitive improvements as measured by the B-CAM. Adherence and acceptability were good, though cognitive benefits were not observed.
population_specificity: People with HIV
effective_dosage: High-Intensity Interval Training and resistance exercises 3 days/week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of an online HIIT intervention and health education on behaviors, mental health, and cognitive function in sedentary young females.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of HIIT, only stating that a pilot trial was conducted.
population_specificity: Sedentary young Chinese females aged 18-30 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of moderate intensity training (MIT) and sprint intensity training (SIT) on cytokine responses and Klotho levels in healthy, sedentary men.
results_summary: Both MIT and SIT similarly improved cardiovascular fitness (VO₂ max), but SIT resulted in intensity-specific changes in cytokine responses compared to MIT.
population_specificity: Healthy, sedentary men (n=22)
effective_dosage: SIT: 6 sessions over 2 weeks, each session consisting of 6 × 30s all-out cycle ergometer sprints with 4min recovery between sprints. MIT: 6 sessions over 2 weeks, cycle ergometer exercise at 60% VO₂ max.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the acute gluco-regulatory and physiological responses of high-intensity interval exercise and resistance exercise in recreationally active individuals.
results_summary: The study found a significant interaction between time and intervention for glucose, indicating that both high-intensity interval exercise and resistance exercise effectively lower blood glucose, though potential differences in regulatory mechanisms remain unclear.
population_specificity: Sixteen recreationally active individuals (eight males and eight females), aged 22 ± 7 years.
effective_dosage: Twelve 30-second cycling intervals at 80% of peak power capacity with 90-second active recovery (matched duration for resistance exercise).
study_duration: Single session with a seven-day washout period between interventions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of inspiratory muscle training (IMT) and High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) on oxygen saturation (SpO₂) in breath-hold divers.
results_summary: The study found that IMT reduced SpO₂ by more than 3 seconds, but the abstract does not provide specific results for HIIT's effects.
population_specificity: Fifteen breath-hold divers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare changes in health-related quality of life (QoL) among hypertensive, obese, and physically inactive individuals following different 16-week aerobic exercise programs, including high-volume HIIT and low-volume HIIT, versus an attention control group.
results_summary: The study found that hypertensive individuals had lower baseline QoL scores compared to healthy controls. Different exercise programs, including HIIT, were evaluated for their impact on QoL, but specific results regarding HIIT's effectiveness were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Physically inactive, obese individuals with primary hypertension (n = 253) compared to a healthy sample (n = 30).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of a 3-month indoor cycling program on reducing cardiometabolic risk factors in women aged 40-60 with obesity.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study compares the effects of the indoor cycling program on cardiometabolic risk factors.
population_specificity: Women aged 40-60 years with obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether home-based HIIT using telerehabilitation improves cardiorespiratory fitness and peak oxygen uptake more effectively than traditional MICT in coronary heart disease patients.
results_summary: The study suggests that HIIT may be superior to MICT in improving cardiorespiratory fitness, with telemonitored home-based training showing feasibility. Secondary outcomes included improvements in health-related quality of life, anxiety, and body composition.
population_specificity: Coronary heart disease patients at low to moderate cardiovascular risk post-cardiac event.
effective_dosage: Not specified (HIIT protocol details not provided in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential benefits and limitations of exercise and/or protein supplementation for lean body mass retention during very-low-energy diets.
results_summary: Current studies suggest that both protein supplementation and exercise training may improve lean body mass retention and skeletal muscle function during very-low-energy diets, though outcomes vary due to intervention heterogeneity and discordant literature findings.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and older adults who are overweight or obese and prone to sarcopenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of a 12-week recumbent arm/leg stepping HIIT program in persons with multiple sclerosis and walking disability (pwMS-wd) and examine its effects on aerobic fitness, physical activity, ambulation, cognition, fatigue, and depression.
results_summary: The study will evaluate feasibility and secondary outcomes like aerobic capacity, physical activity, and cognitive function at baseline, midpoint, and post-intervention, but specific results are not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Persons with multiple sclerosis and walking disability (pwMS-wd)
effective_dosage: 10 cycles of 60-second intervals at wattage associated with 90% VO2 peak, 2-3 times per week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of HIIT on clinical variables of Metabolic Syndrome (MetS) in adults compared to non-exercising controls.
results_summary: HIIT significantly improved fasting blood glucose, systolic and diastolic blood pressure, and waist circumference, with a slight increase in HDL-C, but no significant change in triglycerides.
population_specificity: Adults with Metabolic Syndrome (MetS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare short- and long-term dietary intake effects of HIIT versus moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) in cardiac rehabilitation patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between HIIT and MICT in energy intake, dietary behavior, food preferences, or appetite-related measures over 12 months, suggesting HIIT does not lead to compensatory dietary changes.
population_specificity: 93 participants with coronary artery disease enrolled in a cardiac rehabilitation program.
effective_dosage: 4x4-minute HIIT sessions or 40-minute MICT sessions, 3 times per week (2 supervised, 1 home-based).
study_duration: 4 weeks of supervised rehabilitation followed by 48 weeks of home-based sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) improves neurocognition in schizophrenia patients more effectively than active video gaming (AVG).
results_summary: Both HIIT and AVG significantly improved neurocognitive composite scores from baseline to post-intervention and follow-up, with no significant difference between the two interventions. Unexpected trends suggested differential effects in learning subdomains (HIIT improved verbal learning, AVG improved visual learning).
population_specificity: 82 outpatients diagnosed with schizophrenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) on cardiometabolic health, perceived work ability, and well-being in severely obese individuals.
results_summary: HIIT led to significant weight reduction (5.3 kg) and improvements in VO₂max and work ability compared to the control group, which showed smaller weight loss (3.7 kg) and no significant changes in VO₂max or work ability.
population_specificity: Severely obese individuals (BMI: 39.6 ± 7.1 kg/m²) with sedentary occupations, aged 48.7 ± 9.9 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the mechanisms behind reduced exercise capacity in heart transplant patients and evaluate the clinical effects of high-intensity interval training compared to conventional rehabilitation strategies.
results_summary: The study suggests that high-intensity interval training offers significant benefits for heart transplant recipients over conventional exercise protocols, improving exercise capacity through multifactorial effects. Current evidence supports its effectiveness in this population.
population_specificity: Heart transplant recipients

study_goal: To evaluate the impact of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) on health-related outcomes in cancer prehabilitation.
results_summary: HIIT significantly improved peak oxygen consumption (VO2) and was deemed feasible and safe for cancer patients, though larger trials on long-term effects like recurrence or survival are lacking.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with cancer undergoing prehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and safety of different exercise modes, including High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT), in patients with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (AF).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding HIIT's effects, as the study is still in the pilot phase and focused on feasibility and safety assessments.
population_specificity: Patients aged 60-80 years with paroxysmal AF.
effective_dosage: 4×4 min at 75%-85% peak power output, twice weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) versus Moderate-Intensity Continuous Training (MICT) on exercise capacity, peak heart rate, and heart rate reserve in heart transplant recipients.
results_summary: HIIT significantly improved peak oxygen consumption (peakVO2), peak heart rate, and heart rate reserve compared to MICT, with statistically significant results (P<0.0001 for peakVO2, P=0.009 for peak heart rate, and P=0.05 for heart rate reserve).
population_specificity: Heart transplant recipients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how a 4-week mesocycle of intensified endurance training would affect markers of Relative Energy Deficiency in Sports (RED-S) in well-trained male cyclists.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of the training on RED-S markers or performance outcomes.
population_specificity: Well-trained male cyclists (age: 33.5 ± 6.6 years, height: 181.4 ± 5.2 cm, weight: 76.5 ± 7.4 kg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effect of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) on resting blood pressure in older adults against other time-efficient interventions.
results_summary: HIIT led to a statistically significant reduction in resting systolic blood pressure (9 mmHg) in healthy older adults after 6 weeks, with no significant changes in diastolic blood pressure or pulse pressure.
population_specificity: Healthy, community-dwelling older adults (mean age: 71 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified (supervised HIIT on a cycle ergometer).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to measure changes in ambulatory and clinic blood pressure following a 4-week HIIT intervention in physically inactive adults.
results_summary: The study found that HIIT significantly reduced 24-hour ambulatory systolic and diastolic blood pressure, as well as clinic systolic blood pressure, compared to the control group. Additionally, HIIT improved blood pressure variability, which is a key factor in cardiovascular disease risk.
population_specificity: Physically inactive adults (mean age 22.8 ± 2.7 years).
effective_dosage: 3 × 30-second maximal sprints on a cycle ergometer (7.5% bodyweight resistance), separated by 2-minute active recovery periods.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the acute and chronic effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) versus Moderate-Intensity Continuous Exercise (MICE) on heart rate (HR) and heart rate variability (HRV) in individuals recovering from acute ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).
results_summary: The study found a trend for acute increases in HR during sleep after HIIT, while chronic effects on resting HR and HRV tended to be more beneficial after MICE than HIIT. Low- and high-frequency power of HRV decreased in the HIIT group but increased in the MICE group.
population_specificity: Individuals within 7 weeks after acute ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention duration and frequency implied but not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of five years of supervised high-intensity interval training (HIIT) and moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) versus standard physical activity recommendations on all-cause mortality in older adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in all-cause mortality between the combined HIIT/MICT group and the control group. However, HIIT showed a trend toward lower mortality compared to both the control group and MICT, with an absolute risk reduction of 2.9 percentage points when compared to MICT.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 70-77 years in Trondheim, Norway, with generally good health and medium/high baseline physical activity levels.
effective_dosage: Two sessions weekly of HIIT at ~90% of peak heart rate or MICT at ~70% of peak heart rate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) compared to lower-intensity training (LIT) in reducing anxiety and related symptoms in patients with generalized anxiety disorder (GAD).
results_summary: HIIT showed generally twice the effect size of LIT in reducing anxiety, depression, stress-related symptoms, and improving perceived control over anxiety. The effects were moderate to large and sustained at 30-day follow-up.
population_specificity: 33 patients with generalized anxiety disorder (GAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a flow-resistive face mask and inspiratory muscle training (IMT) on 5 km performance when used during high-intensity interval training (HIIT).
results_summary: HIIT improved 5 km time trial performance in all groups, but IMT showed greater improvement than the mask or control. The flow-resistive mask provided no additional benefit to performance compared to HIIT alone.
population_specificity: 23 participants (13 males)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) combined with resistance training (RT) versus moderate continuous training (MCT) combined with RT on inflammatory and lipid profiles in individuals with type 2 diabetes (T2DM).
results_summary: Both HIIT with RT and MCT with RT improved Interleukin-6 (IL-6) levels, but only HIIT with RT showed significant improvements in total cholesterol and LDL-C compared to the control group. No significant effects were observed for other inflammatory or lipid markers like CRP, cortisol, TNF-α, sCD163, triglycerides, or HDL-C.
population_specificity: Individuals with type 2 diabetes (n=80, aged 59 years).
effective_dosage: Supervised exercise sessions 3 days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the peri-operative functional trajectory of patients undergoing two different exercise protocols (HIIT vs. MICT) within a 4-week multimodal prehabilitation program.
results_summary: Both HIIT and MICT significantly improved pre-operative functional capacity with no difference between groups. At 2 months post-surgery, the HIIT group showed a higher improvement in physical fitness compared to MICT. No adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Adult patients scheduled for elective resection of nonmetastatic colorectal cancer with no absolute contraindications to exercise or poor language comprehension.
study_duration: 4 weeks prehabilitation, with follow-up assessments at 1 and 2 months post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and benefits of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) combined with lifestyle education in inactive adults with celiac disease.
results_summary: The HIIT+ group showed enrichment in relative abundance of certain outcomes post-intervention, with participants reaching a mean of 97.9% of age-predicted maximum heart rate and an average perceived exertion of 6.33 out of 10 during HIIT intervals.
population_specificity: Inactive adults with celiac disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility and effects of combining High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) with resistance training (RT) in older adults with HIV to address reduced cardiorespiratory fitness.
results_summary: The study found that HIIT combined with RT was feasible and implemented in sedentary older adults with HIV, though specific efficacy outcomes were not detailed in the abstract. The intervention involved a cross-over design, with participants initially randomized to continuous high-intensity aerobic exercise and RT or a control group.
population_specificity: Sedentary adults with HIV aged ≥50 years, predominantly African American (63%) and male (95%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize existing literature on exercise training, including High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT), to provide evidence-based guidelines for improving exercise capacity and health-related quality of life in individuals with COPD.
results_summary: The study found that HIIT, along with other alternative exercise modes, improves exercise outcomes in adults with COPD compared to no exercise, enhancing exercise capacity, reducing symptoms like dyspnea and fatigue, and improving health-related quality of life.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) versus moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) on peak oxygen consumption (V̇O₂) in patients with left ventricular assist devices (LVADs).
results_summary: HIIT significantly improved peak oxygen consumption more than MICT, with no major adverse events reported in either group. The findings suggest HIIT is well-tolerated and more effective for increasing aerobic capacity in LVAD patients.
population_specificity: Clinically stable patients with left ventricular assist devices (LVADs), aged 55.6 ± 14.2 to 57.7 ± 13.1 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exercise, including High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT), could counteract chemotherapy-induced inflammation and reduce fatigue in breast cancer patients.
results_summary: RT-HIIT significantly reduced increases in IL-6 and CD8a compared to usual care, mediating lower fatigue levels. AT-HIIT showed no significant differences in inflammatory markers versus usual care.
population_specificity: Women with breast cancer undergoing adjuvant chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: 16 weeks of combined resistance and HIIT (RT-HIIT) or moderate-intensity aerobic and HIIT (AT-HIIT).

study_goal: To investigate the feasibility of aquatic high-intensity interval training for adolescents with cerebral palsy who can ambulate independently.
results_summary: The study found that aquatic high-intensity interval training was feasible, with 93% of exercise stations achieving the target heart rate intensity. Participants reported enjoyment and no major adverse events, though efficacy remains uncertain.
population_specificity: Ambulant adolescents with cerebral palsy (14 years 7 months ± 2 years 0 months).
effective_dosage: Ten weeks of twice-weekly sessions, each comprising 10 one-minute exercise intervals separated by one-minute rest.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary efficacy of a 6-week handcycling HIIT program for wheelchair users with spinal cord injury.
results_summary: The study found that handcycling HIIT was feasible and acceptable, with high participant enjoyment and satisfaction. While 71% of participants reported improved endurance, function, and health, objective physiological changes showed mixed results.
population_specificity: Wheelchair users with spinal cord injury.
effective_dosage: Two weekly, 25-minute sessions (1-minute work intervals at 90% peak power output, 1-minute recovery intervals at 0-20% peak power output).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the immediate and training effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) versus moderate continuous training on neutrophil-to-lymphocyte ratio (NLR) and related cellular inflammation markers in persons with multiple sclerosis (PwMS).
results_summary: Only HIIT reduced the NLR over the 3-week intervention period, suggesting potential anti-inflammatory effects through repetitive inflammatory states with compensatory anti-inflammatory responses after each session.
population_specificity: Persons with multiple sclerosis (PwMS) undergoing inpatient rehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare affective and social cognitive responses to low-volume HIIT and MICT in a progressive two-week intervention for individuals at risk of type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Both HIIT and MICT showed increases in post-exercise enjoyment, attitudes, and intentions to exercise, with MICT reporting more positive in-task affect and affective attitudes. Positive correlations between affective and social cognitive responses were observed.
population_specificity: Low-active, overweight adults at risk of type 2 diabetes (n=99).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-intensity interval exercise (HIIE) and moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) on various health outcomes, including physical fitness, body composition, and metabolic markers.
results_summary: HIIE was superior to MICT in improving cardiovascular health (V˙O2max and FMD), while MICT was better for long-term glucose metabolism (HbA1c). No significant differences were found for other outcomes like body composition, blood pressure, or lipid profiles.
population_specificity: Not specified (meta-analysis of 55 studies with varied populations).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-intensity interval training improves cardiorespiratory fitness (measured by VO₂ max) in patients with schizophrenia compared to computer gaming skills training.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in cardiorespiratory fitness between the high-intensity interval training and control groups post-intervention, though 47% of the training group showed a ≥5% increase in VO₂ max. Despite increased treadmill workload in 61% of participants, within-group improvements were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: 82 patients with schizophrenia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the impact of exercise intensity (HIIT vs. moderate-intensity training) on aerobic fitness, cardiac regulation, and stress biomarkers in breast cancer survivors to assess CVD risk reduction.
results_summary: HIIT significantly improved cardiovascular fitness (VO₂) and cardiac regulation, with some individuals showing improved sympathetic nervous system responses. The study concluded HIIT was safe and effective for breast cancer survivors, offering time-efficient benefits for physical health and stress reduction.
population_specificity: Breast cancer survivors (mean age 62 ± 8 years).
effective_dosage: 36 sessions of stationary cycling over 12 weeks (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the feasibility, safety, adherence, and efficacy of HIIT versus moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) for improving VO2 peak in patients with coronary artery disease (CAD).
results_summary: HIIT improved VO2 peak by 10% after 4 weeks compared to 4% with MICT, though improvements were similar at 12 months. Both interventions were feasible and safe, with low rates of serious adverse events, but adherence declined during home-based training.
population_specificity: Patients with angiographically proven CAD, aged 18-80 years (mean age 65, 84% male).
effective_dosage: 4 × 4-minute HIIT sessions or 40-minute MICT sessions, 3 times per week (2 supervised, 1 home-based for 4 weeks, then 3 home-based sessions per week).
study_duration: 4 weeks of supervised training followed by 48 weeks of home-based training (total 12 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of a workplace-integrated HIIT intervention on physical and mental health outcomes in sedentary adults.
results_summary: The study found high participant satisfaction (4.6/5), 71% adherence to ≥2 sessions/week, and an average heart rate of 85.9%, indicating feasibility. Physiological and psychological outcomes were measured, but specific efficacy results are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Sedentary university employees (n=47, 43.0±10.7 years; 41 female).
effective_dosage: 2-3 researcher-facilitated HIIT sessions/week, each including a 2-minute warm-up and 8-minute exercise combinations (30:30 work:rest intervals).
study_duration: 8 weeks (weeks 1-8), with outcomes measured at 9 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIT) versus Moderate Intensity Continuous Training (MICT) on health-related quality of life (HRQoL) in de novo heart transplant recipients.
results_summary: Both HIT and MICT improved physical function scores of HRQoL, with no significant differences between groups except for a larger increase in the Role Emotional subscale in the HIT arm. Mental health scores remained unchanged in both groups.
population_specificity: De novo heart transplant recipients (n=78 completed the intervention).
effective_dosage: HIT: 2-4 interval bouts at 85-95% of maximal effort; MICT: 25 minutes at 60-80% of maximal effort.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) and Moderate Continuous Training (MCT) on peak oxygen uptake (VO2peak) in cardiac rehabilitation and identify potential moderator variables.
results_summary: HIIT significantly improved VO2peak more than MCT, with greater increases (mean difference = 4.61 ml·kg-1·min-1 vs. 3.23 for MCT). Heterogeneity was moderate for MCT but not significant for HIIT, with subgroup analyses revealing key moderators for MCT's effects.
population_specificity: Patients with coronary artery disease undergoing cardiac rehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) on retinal microvasculature in type 1 diabetes patients without clinical signs of diabetic retinopathy.
results_summary: HIIT significantly improved physical fitness, with large increases in power output at the lactate threshold and maximal power output. However, the study suggested that disease-specific training protocols might be needed to address potentially impaired retinal microvascular adaptations.
population_specificity: Twenty type 1 diabetes patients without clinical signs of diabetic retinopathy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (four weeks of HIIT, but exact frequency/intensity not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of HIIT, resistance training, combined training, and nutritional guidance on local fat/lean mass indexes in adults with excess adiposity and assess individual response patterns.
results_summary: The study found significant decreases in body weight, arm, trunk, and leg fat mass, as well as android and gynoid fat mass in HIIT, RT, and CT groups after 12 weeks.
population_specificity: Adults with excess adiposity

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-intensity interval training combined with resistance training (HIIT + RT) versus moderate-intensity continuous training combined with resistance training (MICT + RT) on cardiometabolic risk factors in adolescents.
results_summary: Both HIIT + RT and MICT + RT significantly reduced cardiometabolic risk scores in adolescents, with HIIT + RT showing a notable effect compared to the control group. Significant improvements were observed in body fat percentage, blood pressure, and VO2peak for HIIT + RT, though no significant differences were found between HIIT + RT and MICT + RT.
population_specificity: 76 adolescents (16.1 years, 44 female)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether citrulline supplementation combined with High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) improves physical performance in healthy older adults compared to HIIT alone.
results_summary: The study found that HIIT combined with citrulline supplementation led to greater reductions in BMI and android fat mass, as well as improved gait speeds (both self-paced and fast-paced), compared to HIIT with a placebo.
population_specificity: Sedentary and inactive older adults aged over 65 years with a BMI <30 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of low-volume HIIT, MICT, and a placebo intervention on liver fat, glycemia, and cardiorespiratory fitness in inactive adults with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: HIIT reduced liver fat (-1.7 ± 1.1%) and improved glycemia and cardiorespiratory fitness, outperforming MICT (-0.9 ± 0.7%) and placebo (1.2 ± 0.5%). The study suggests HIIT may benefit metabolic health without weight loss.
population_specificity: Inactive adults (age 54.6 ± 1.4 years, 54% male; BMI 35.9 ± 0.9 kg/m²) with type 2 diabetes.
effective_dosage: 12 minutes of weekly high-intensity aerobic exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) as part of novel exercise interventions for patients across the chronic kidney disease (CKD) spectrum.
results_summary: The abstract highlights HIIT as a promising intervention strategy for CKD patients, but notes that implementation remains scarce due to small sample sizes and methodological limitations in existing studies. Future research is needed to assess larger, more comprehensive interventions.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD), including those prior to dialysis and kidney transplantation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) and resistance training (RES) versus usual care (UC) on cancer-treatment-related fatigue and other outcomes in prostate cancer patients undergoing radiation therapy.
results_summary: HIIT and RES both significantly attenuated increases in cancer-treatment-related fatigue and improved functional exercise capacity compared to UC. No other secondary outcomes differed between groups, and both interventions were safe with excellent attendance rates.
population_specificity: Prostate cancer patients undergoing radiation therapy, with or without androgen deprivation therapy (ADT), aged 69.1 ± 8.2 years.
effective_dosage: HIIT consisted of 8–15 × 60-second intervals (≥85% maximal heart rate), performed three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of exercise, including High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT), on reducing epicardial adipose tissue (EAT) in individuals with overweight/obesity.
results_summary: The study found that exercise, particularly endurance training, significantly reduced EAT, but there was insufficient data to conclusively compare HIIT's effectiveness to moderate-intensity continuous training. Two studies on HIIT showed mixed results—one reported higher benefits with HIIT, while the other found no differences.
population_specificity: Individuals with overweight/obesity (521 participants across 10 studies).
effective_dosage: ≥3 sessions per week (specific HIIT dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the clinical benefits and exercise dose considerations, including High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT), for cardiac rehabilitation patients.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that HIIT is a contemporary training intervention for cardiac patients, emphasizing the importance of exercise dose to improve peak oxygen uptake and physiological adaptation. Behavior change strategies are crucial for long-term adoption of active lifestyles post-cardiac events.
population_specificity: Patients with coronary heart disease and chronic heart failure undergoing community-based cardiac rehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) improves peak oxygen uptake (VO₂ peak), muscular strength, and health-related quality of life (HRQOL) in individuals post-lung transplantation (LTx).
results_summary: HIIT improved muscular strength and HRQOL but did not significantly improve VO₂ peak compared to usual care. The study had a high completion rate (23/25 in the intervention group).
population_specificity: Individuals 6 to 60 months post-lung transplantation (LTx).
effective_dosage: Supervised HIIT program consisting of endurance and strength training 3 times a week.

study_goal: To study the effect of 12 weeks of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) on glycemic control in adults with type 1 diabetes and overweight or obesity.
results_summary: The study found no significant reduction in HbA1c levels after 12 weeks of HIIT, indicating limited efficacy for glycemic control in this population.
population_specificity: Inactive adults with type 1 diabetes and BMI ≥25 kg/m² (overweight or obese).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, feasibility, tolerability, and acceptability of a HIIT programme for patients with intermittent claudication.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, and results are not yet available; it is designed to inform a future pilot randomised controlled trial comparing HIIT to usual-care supervised exercise programmes.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication (IC).
effective_dosage: 10×1 min high-intensity cycling intervals at 85%-90% peak power output, interspaced with 10×1 min low-intensity intervals at 20%-25% peak power output, 3 times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of low-volume HIIT versus MICT and a placebo control on central arterial stiffness, hemodynamic responses, and CVD risk factors in adults with obesity and type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that 12 minutes of low-volume HIIT per week improved central arterial stiffness and cardiovascular health in inactive individuals with obesity and T2D. The results suggest HIIT may be a time-efficient alternative to MICT for improving cardiovascular outcomes in this population.
population_specificity: Inactive adults with obesity and type 2 diabetes (average age 55.1 years, BMI 36.1 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 1 × 4 min cycling at 90% peak oxygen consumption (V̇O₂ peak) per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether early initiation (14 days post-surgery) of a structured rehabilitation program, including High-Intensity Interval Training, improves Health-Related Quality of Life (HRQoL) in lung cancer patients compared to late initiation (14 weeks post-surgery).
results_summary: Early rehabilitation (ERG) led to continuous HRQoL improvement up to 26 weeks, followed by a decline without further intervention, while late rehabilitation (LRG) initially showed non-significant deterioration but improved after the 12-week program, though not to ERG levels.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent surgery for lung cancer.
effective_dosage: High-intensity interval training and strength exercise twice a week for 12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) on inflammatory markers and adipo-cytokines compared to control conditions or moderate-intensity continuous training in individuals with metabolic disorders.
results_summary: HIIT improved circulating adiponectin, leptin, and TNF-α compared to control conditions, but no differences were observed for IL-6 and CRP. Intervention duration moderated the effects on IL-6 and leptin.
population_specificity: Individuals with metabolic disorders (diabetes, metabolic syndrome, polycystic ovary syndrome, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, or overweight/obesity).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) and Moderate-Intensity Continuous Training (MICT), both combined with strengthening and stretching exercises, in women with fibromyalgia.
results_summary: HIIT and MICT both significantly improved fibromyalgia impact, pain, functional capacity, and quality of life compared to the control group, but HIIT was not superior to MICT. Only the MICT group showed significant improvements in body composition parameters.
population_specificity: Women with fibromyalgia (N=60, 55 completed).
effective_dosage: HIIT: 5-minute warm-up at 50% peak heart rate, 4 cycles of 4 minutes at 80%-95% peak heart rate with 3-minute recovery intervals at 70% peak heart rate, 5 sessions per week. MICT: 45 minutes at 65%-70% peak heart rate, 5 sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) versus moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) on blood pressure and arterial stiffness parameters in young athletes.
results_summary: HIIT significantly reduced peripheral and central blood pressure, pulse wave velocity, augmentation pressure, and augmentation index in young athletes, while the control group showed no significant changes. The intervention group demonstrated superior outcomes compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Adolescent rowers (aged 15±1.3 years).
effective_dosage: HIIT was performed twice weekly (2×4×2 min at ≈95% of maximum heart rate, with 60 s rest) in addition to regular rowing training (3×/week MICT, 70-90 min at ≈70% HR<inf>max</inf>).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 4-week HIIT intervention improves left atrial (LA) mechanics and aortic stiffness in physically inactive individuals.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in LA mechanics (reservoir, conduit, and contractile functions) and aortic distensibility following HIIT compared to the control group. These adaptations suggest HIIT may enhance cardiovascular health by improving diastolic and systolic mechanics.
population_specificity: Forty-one physically inactive males and females.
effective_dosage: 3 × 30-second maximal cycle ergometer sprints at 7.5% body weight resistance, interspersed with 2-minute active recovery, three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) on cardiorespiratory fitness during cisplatin-based chemotherapy for testicular cancer.
results_summary: The study found an unexpected high number of thromboembolic events (pulmonary embolism and myocardial infarction) in the HIIT intervention arm, leading to premature trial closure. No such events occurred in the control arm.
population_specificity: Males aged 18-60 with metastatic germ cell testicular cancer undergoing cisplatin-based chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: Two weekly HIIT sessions, each with 2-4 intervals of 2-4 minutes at 85-95% of peak heart rate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether early initiation of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIT) had a lasting effect on peak oxygen consumption (VO₂) in heart transplant recipients.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study compared HIT with moderate-intensity continuous training over 9 months and followed up for 3 years to assess long-term effects.
population_specificity: De novo heart transplant recipients in Scandinavia.
study_duration: 9 months of intervention, with a 3-year follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of exercise interventions, particularly High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT), on improving lipid metabolism and preventing age-related liver disorders in middle-aged and elderly populations.
results_summary: The study concluded that exercise interventions, especially HIIT, can prevent and improve age-related liver disease, with future research needed to determine optimal intensity and duration. Nutritional and pharmacological interventions were also noted to improve liver disorders, but exercise was highlighted as a key focus.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and elderly individuals with a focus on aging-related metabolic and liver health.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of low-volume HIIT and higher-volume MICT on cardiometabolic and psychological responses in overweight/obese middle-aged men.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study compared HIIT and MICT interventions, suggesting a focus on their relative effectiveness for metabolic health.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese middle-aged men (age: 48.1±5.2yr; BMI: 25.8±2.3kg·m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) versus moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) and usual care (UC) on cardiorespiratory fitness (peak V̇O₂).
results_summary: HIIT showed significantly higher peak V̇O₂ compared to MICT and UC, with adherence rates ranging between 71.2% and 95.6%. No serious adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: 516 participants with post-intervention cardiopulmonary exercise testing (CPET) data.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to demonstrate the added value of spectral CT, including iodine density mapping, in improving diagnostic performance and patient care in emergency department settings.
results_summary: Spectral CT, utilizing iodine density mapping, enhances diagnostic accuracy for inflammatory and ischemic conditions, organ perfusion assessment, lesion characterization, and mass detection while enabling lower contrast medium volumes without increased radiation dose.
population_specificity: Patients in emergency department settings with acute conditions requiring CT imaging.

study_goal: To investigate the safety and efficacy of a stent combined with a linear strand of iodine seeds for treating malignant cancer-associated venous obstruction.
results_summary: The study reported a high surgery success rate (96.5%) with no serious complications, and symptoms of venous obstruction improved significantly post-surgery. Group A showed a notable reduction in symptom scores from 14.74 to 2.79 points.
population_specificity: 57 patients with malignant cancer-associated venous obstruction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the evolution and diagnostic criteria of noninvasive follicular thyroid neoplasm with papillary-like nuclear features (NIFTP) and its molecular and clinical implications.
results_summary: The study found that NIFTP has a distinct biological behavior, with recent revisions excluding high-risk genetic abnormalities and confirming no recurrence or metastatic risk in large or oncocytic variants. Molecularly, NIFTP shares a similar mutational profile with other follicular thyroid neoplasms but exhibits heterogeneous transcriptomic features.
population_specificity: Patients with thyroid lesions, specifically NIFTP.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antimicrobial properties of iodine compounds, particularly their effects on biofilm prevention and treatment in chronic wounds.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that iodine compounds have multiple antimicrobial interactions effective against biofilm phenotypes, which are often resistant to other treatments. An expert panel discussed these properties, suggesting potential benefits in wound care.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic non-healing lesions such as venous leg ulcers and diabetic foot ulcers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate strategies for minimizing aerosolized pathogens in orthodontic procedures, including the potential use of povidone iodine as a preprocedural mouth rinse in specific conditions.
results_summary: The study suggests povidone iodine (0.2%-1%) as a substitute strategy for reducing viral loads in aerosolized pathogens, particularly in the presence of oxidation-vulnerable viruses, alongside other measures like water-spray minimization and protective equipment.
population_specificity: Orthodontic patients and treatment teams exposed to aerosolized pathogens during procedures.
effective_dosage: 0.2%-1% povidone iodine (concentration mentioned, but frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of oncogene-specific targeted therapies, including iodine-related treatments, as neoadjuvant therapy for pediatric patients with advanced invasive thyroid cancer.
results_summary: Preliminary data suggest that systemic therapy, including targeted oncogene treatments, may effectively induce tumor regression in pediatric patients with unresectable invasive thyroid cancer, reducing surgical risks and improving outcomes. The study highlights the potential for these therapies to replace or precede surgery in high-risk cases.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with unresectable invasive thyroid cancer, including those with extensive disease involving trachea, esophagus, or vascular/neural structures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical outcomes of two preparation methods (thyroid hormone withdrawal vs. recombinant human thyroid-stimulating hormone) for radioactive iodine adjuvant therapy in patients with intermediate- to high-risk differentiated thyroid carcinoma.
results_summary: No significant differences were found between the two preparation methods in achieving the initial therapy goal, but the rhTSH group had higher TSH levels and better retained kidney function (eGFR).
population_specificity: Patients with intermediate- to high-risk differentiated thyroid carcinoma post-thyroidectomy, without metastatic or residual lesions.
study_duration: 3-week iodine restriction with thyroxine withdrawal or 2-week iodine restriction with rhTSH administration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare infection rates among patients undergoing gynecological laparoscopies using three different skin preparation solutions, including alcohol-based povidone-iodine and water-based povidone-iodine.
results_summary: The study found no significant advantage of either iodine-based solution (alcohol-based or water-based povidone-iodine) over alcohol-based chlorhexidine in reducing surgical site infections. Infection rates were higher than expected, with no statistically significant differences between the three solutions.
population_specificity: 661 patients aged 18 or older undergoing elective operative laparoscopy for nonmalignant gynecological disorders.
effective_dosage: Not specified (used as skin preparation solution).
